articles.headline: Union Critical of Obama’s Top Economics Aide
articles.snippet: Labor leaders say Jason Furman, Barack Obama’s new economic policy director, focuses too much on corporate America and not enough on workers.
articles.abstract: Labor leaders say Jason Furman, Barack Obama’s new economic policy director, focuses too much on corporate America and not enough on workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Acting quickly after securing his party’s presidential nomination, Barack Obama picked a well-known representative of Bill Clinton’s economic policies as his economic policy director and signaled this week that the major players from the Clinton economics team were now in his camp  starting with Robert E. Rubin.

articles.headline: An Imitator That Rivals the iPhone
articles.snippet: Sprint’s new Samsung Instinct is an iPhone wannabe, but it has its own personality.
articles.abstract: Sprint’s new Samsung Instinct is an iPhone wannabe, but it has its own personality.
articles.lead_paragraph: The story so far: Apple introduced the iPhone a year ago, and has sold six million of them. Then on Monday, Apple unveiled an improved model that brings faster Internet, G.P.S. and a much lower price to an already well-designed device.

articles.headline: Unlike Others, U.S. Defends Freedom to Offend in Speech
articles.snippet: As more countries move to ban or restrict hate speech, some legal scholars say the U.S. should reconsider the broad scope of First Amendment protection.
articles.abstract: As more countries move to ban or restrict hate speech, some legal scholars say the U.S. should reconsider the broad scope of First Amendment protection.
articles.lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  A couple of years ago, a Canadian magazine published an article arguing that the rise of Islam threatened Western values. The article’s tone was mocking and biting, but it said nothing that conservative magazines and blogs in the United States do not say every day without fear of legal reprisal.

articles.headline: Hedge Funds Can Vote at CSX Meeting
articles.snippet: A federal judge who ruled that two hedge funds seeking to win a proxy fight at CSX had violated securities laws also said that there was nothing effective that he could do about it.
articles.abstract: A federal judge who ruled that two hedge funds seeking to win a proxy fight at CSX had violated securities laws also said that there was nothing effective that he could do about it.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal judge ruled Wednesday that two hedge funds seeking to win a proxy fight at the CSX Corporation had violated securities laws by not disclosing their positions and intentions many months before they did.

articles.headline: American Aid Is Seized in Zimbabwe
articles.snippet: Food for schoolchildren was ordered to be given to backers of President Robert Mugabe, the U.S. ambassador said.
articles.abstract: Food for schoolchildren was ordered to be given to backers of President Robert Mugabe, the U.S. ambassador said.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG  Zimbabwean authorities confiscated a truck loaded with 20 tons of American food aid for poor schoolchildren and ordered that the wheat and pinto beans aboard be handed out to supporters of President Robert Mugabe at a political rally instead, the American ambassador said Wednesday.

articles.headline: Rough Events at Mexican Rodeos in U.S. Criticized
articles.snippet: The charreada, a type of rodeo popular among a growing number of middle-class Mexican-Americans, is facing criticism over some of its events.
articles.abstract: The charreada, a type of rodeo popular among a growing number of middle-class Mexican-Americans, is facing criticism over some of its events.
articles.lead_paragraph: TURLOCK, Calif.  It always begins at noon in a dusty arena, with brisk salutes on the brims of glittering sombreros and mustachioed horsemen in three-piece suits.

articles.headline: Commodity Prices Show No Letup
articles.snippet: Heavy rains and cool weather in the Midwest are driving up the price of corn, while other commodity prices like oil, soybeans and wheat also jumped on Wednesday.
articles.abstract: Heavy rains and cool weather in the Midwest are driving up the price of corn, while other commodity prices like oil, soybeans and wheat also jumped on Wednesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  Commodity prices went wild on Wednesday, with the price of corn shooting through the $7 barrier for the first time, soybeans and wheat moving up sharply and oil jumping more than $5 a barrel.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: Pakistan Angry as Strike by U.S. Kills 11 Soldiers
articles.snippet: The Pakistani government softened its response, but the military called the strikes “unprovoked and cowardly.”
articles.abstract: The Pakistani government softened its response, but the military called the strikes “unprovoked and cowardly.”
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  American air and artillery strikes killed 11 Pakistani paramilitary soldiers during a clash with insurgents on the Afghan border on Tuesday night, a development that raised concerns about the already strained American relationship with Pakistan.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Obama Aide Quits Under Fire for His Business Ties
articles.snippet: The resignation of James A. Johnson highlights the challenge Barack Obama faces in living up to his goal of not surrounding himself with people with ties to special interests.
articles.abstract: The resignation of James A. Johnson highlights the challenge Barack Obama faces in living up to his goal of not surrounding himself with people with ties to special interests.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  James A. Johnson, the consummate Washington insider whom Senator Barack Obama tapped to head his vice-presidential search effort, resigned abruptly on Wednesday to try to silence a growing furor over his business activities.
articles.byline: By John M. Broder and Leslie Wayne

articles.headline: Housing Slump Helps the Draw of Fixer-Upper TV
articles.snippet: A shift in focus away from shows on buying real estate to more educational and emotional offerings is fueling a boom in television shows about housing.
articles.abstract: A shift in focus away from shows on buying real estate to more educational and emotional offerings is fueling a boom in television shows about housing.
articles.lead_paragraph: The housing market is collapsing, but television shows about housing are booming.

articles.headline: Brewer Bids $46 Billion for Anheuser-Busch
articles.snippet: The unsolicited takeover offer from InBev of Belgium, if accepted, would create the world’s largest brewer.
articles.abstract: The unsolicited takeover offer from InBev of Belgium, if accepted, would create the world’s largest brewer.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the nation’s most prominent family-run companies, Anheuser-Busch, formally became the target of a $46.4 billion unsolicited takeover offer from InBev of Belgium on Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced
